title: Classification of low-dimensional complete gradient Yamabe solitons

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper, we completely classify nontrivial nonflat three-dimensional complete gradient Yamabe solitons. Furthermore, by considering Ricci solitons from the point of view of Yamabe solitons, we provide a proof of the complete classification of nontrivial two-dimensional complete gradient Ricci solitons.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

As is well known, the geometric flow is one of the most powerful tools for understanding the structure of Riemannian manifolds. In particular, the Yamabe flow is one of the central fields of the theory and has developed rapidly (cf. [2], [3]). Gradient Yamabe solitons are self similar solutions of the Yamabe flow and expected to be a singularity model. Therefore, the classification problem is one of the most important ones. To classify gradient Yamabe solitons, there are many studies with curvature assumptions and locally conformally flat conditions (cf. [10], [8], [6] and [12]). These studies give affirmative partial answers to the Yamabe soliton version of the Perelman conjecture, that is, any nontrivial complete steady gradient Yamabe soliton is rotationally symmetric. Recently, the author solved the problem (cf. [13]).

In order to gain a deeper understanding of gradient Yamabe solitons, we consider complete gradient Yamabe solitons without assuming any curvature assumptions. In this paper, we completely classify nontrivial non-flat three-dimensional complete gradient Yamabe solitons. We also provide examples of complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons, which do not appear in the steady and shrinking cases.

For two-dimensional solitons, Yamabe and Ricci solitons can be regarded as equivalent. As is well known, gradient Ricci solitons play an important role in the study of the Ricci flow. Therefore, classification

Using this idea, we provide a proof of the classification of nontrivial two-dimensional complete gradient Ricci and Yamabe solitons. For two-dimensional solitons, similar results were given by Bernstein and Mettler (cf. [1]) using different arguments.

Remark 1.1. As is well known, the original Perelman conjecture [14] is that any three-dimensional complete noncompact $\kappa$-noncollapsed steady gradient Ricci soliton with positive curvature is rotationally symmetric, which was proven by S. Brendle [4] (see also [5]).

# 2. Preliminary 

An $n$ dimensional Riemannian manifold $\left(M^{n}, g\right)$ is called a gradient Yamabe soliton if there exists a smooth function $F$ on $M$ and a constant $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$, such that $\nabla \nabla F=(R-\lambda) g$, where $\nabla \nabla F$ is the Hessian of $F$, and $R$ is the scalar curvature of $M$. If $F$ is constant, then $M$ is called trivial. If $\lambda>0, \lambda=0$, or $\lambda<0$, then the Yamabe soliton is called shrinking, steady, or expanding, respectively.

To classify complete gradient Yamabe solitons, we use Tashiro's theorem ([16], see also [12]).

Theorem 2.1 ([16]). A complete Riemannian manifold $\left(M^{n}, g\right)$ which satisfies that for any smooth functions $F$ and $\varphi$ on $M, \nabla \nabla F=\varphi g$ is either (1) compact and rotationally symmetric, or (2) rotationally symmetric and equal to the warped product $\left([0,+\infty), d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(\mathbb{S}^{n-1}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)$, where $\bar{g}_{S}$ is the round metric on $\mathbb{S}^{n-1}$, and $F$ has one critical point at 0 , or (3) the warped product $\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(N^{n-1}, \bar{g}\right)$, where $F$ has no critical point.

Remark 2.2. The potential function $F$ depends only on $r$, and $F^{\prime}(r)>$ 0 , except at the critical point. It is well known that the manifold $(M, g, F, \varphi)$ that satisfies the condition $\nabla \nabla F=\varphi g$ was studied by Cheeger and Colding [9].

The Riemannian curvature tensor is defined by

$$
R(X, Y) Z=-\nabla_{X} \nabla_{Y} Z+\nabla_{Y} \nabla_{X} Z+\nabla_{[X, Y]} Z
$$

for $X, Y, Z \in \mathfrak{X}(M)$, where $\nabla$ is the Levi-Civita connection of $M$. The Ricci tensor $R_{i j}$ is defined by $R_{i j}=R_{i p j p}$, where, $R_{i j k \ell}=g\left(R\left(\partial_{i}, \partial_{j}\right) \partial_{k}, \partial_{\ell}\right)$.

# 3. Classification of three-dimensional COMPlete Steady GRADIENT Yamabe SOlItons 

In this section, we classify three-dimensional complete steady gradient Yamabe solitons.

Theorem 3.1. Let $(M, g, F)$ be a nontrivial non-flat three-dimensional complete steady gradient Yamabe soliton. Then, $(M, g, F)$ is either
(1) $\left([0,+\infty), d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(\mathbb{S}^{2}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)$ with nonnegative scalar curvature, or
(2) $\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}, \bar{g}_{c a n}\right)$ with nonpositive scalar curvature, or
(3) $\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(\mathbb{S}^{2}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)$. In this case, there exists at least one point, such that, $R=0$.
Proof.

Case (1) of Theorem 2.1. Since $M$ is compact, it is trivial (cf. [11]).
Case (3) of Theorem 2.1.
In this case, by a direct calculation, we can get formulas of the warped product manifold of the warping function $(0<)|\nabla F|=F^{\prime}(r)$. For $a, b, c, d=2,3$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1 a 1 b} & =-F^{\prime} F^{\prime \prime \prime} \bar{g}_{a b}, \quad R_{1 a b c}=0 \\
R_{a b c d} & =\left(F^{\prime}\right)^{2} \bar{R}_{a b c d}+\left(F^{\prime} F^{\prime \prime}\right)^{2}\left(\bar{g}_{a d} \bar{g}_{b c}-\bar{g}_{a c} \bar{g}_{b d}\right) \\
R_{11} & =-2 \frac{F^{\prime \prime \prime}}{F^{\prime}}, \quad R_{1 a}=0 \\
R_{a b}= & \bar{R}_{a b}-\left(\left(F^{\prime \prime}\right)^{2}+F^{\prime} F^{\prime \prime \prime}\right) \bar{g}_{a b} \\
R & =\left(F^{\prime}\right)^{-2} \bar{R}-2\left(\frac{F^{\prime \prime}}{F^{\prime}}\right)^{2}-4 \frac{F^{\prime \prime \prime}}{F^{\prime}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the curvature tensors with bar are the curvature tensors of $(N, \bar{g})$. By (3.3), it is obvious that $\bar{R}$ is constant. Since $\left(N^{2}, \bar{g}\right)$ is a 2 dimensional manifold,

$$
\bar{R}_{a b c d}=-\frac{\bar{R}}{2}\left(\bar{g}_{a d} \bar{g}_{b c}-\bar{g}_{a c} \bar{g}_{b d}\right)
$$

By (3.3) and the soliton equation $R=\rho^{\prime}$, one has

$$
\rho^{2} \rho^{\prime}+2 \rho^{\prime 2}+4 \rho \rho^{\prime \prime}=\bar{R}
$$

where $\rho(r)=F^{\prime}(r)$. By differentiating both sides of (3.5), we have

$$
2 \rho \rho^{\prime 2}+\rho^{2} \rho^{\prime \prime}+8 \rho^{\prime} \rho^{\prime \prime}+4 \rho \rho^{\prime \prime \prime}=0
$$

Assume that $\rho^{\prime} \geq 0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. If $\rho^{\prime \prime} \leq 0$ on $\mathbb{R}$, then the positive function $\rho$ is concave. Hence $\rho$ is constant. By (3.5), $\bar{R}=0$. By (3.4) and (3.1), $M$ is flat. Therefore, $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on some interval $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}\right)$.

If $r_{2}=+\infty$, since $\rho^{\prime} \geq 0, \rho$ goes to infinity as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Hence, the left hand side of (3.5) goes to infinity as $r \nearrow+\infty$, which cannot happen.

Assume that $r_{2}<+\infty$, that is, $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}\right)$ and $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ at $r_{2}$. By (3.6), we have $\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}<0$ at $r_{2}$. Hence, one has $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{2}, r_{3}\right)$ for some $r_{3}$. By the same argument, $\rho^{\prime}$ is monotone decreasing on $\left(r_{2},+\infty\right)$. Without loss of generality, we can assume that the point $r_{2}$ is the first critical one of $\rho^{\prime}$. Since $\rho^{\prime} \geq 0$ and $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(-\infty, r_{2}\right)$, there exists $r_{0} \in\left(-\infty, r_{2}\right)$ such that, $\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}=0$. However, this is contradicted by the equation (3.6).

Therefore, we have $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on some open interval $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}\right)$.
Assume that $r_{2}=+\infty$. Since $\rho$ is a positive monotone decreasing function on $\left(r_{1},+\infty\right), \rho \searrow c$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$ for some positive constant c. If $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{1},+\infty\right)$, then $\rho$ is a positive concave function, which induces that $\rho$ is constant, which is a contradiction. Assume that there exists $\tilde{r} \in\left(r_{1},+\infty\right)$ such that $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$. By (3.6), $\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}(\tilde{r})<0$. Hence, by iterating the same argument, $\rho^{\prime}$ is weakly monotone decreasing on $(\tilde{r},+\infty)$. Hence, $\rho^{\prime}<-\gamma$ for some $\gamma>0$ on $\left(r_{2},+\infty\right)$ for some $r_{2}$. Since $\rho>0$, we have a contradiction. Therefore, one has $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(r_{1},+\infty\right)$ and $\rho^{\prime} \nearrow \alpha$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$ for some constant $\alpha \leq 0$. If $\alpha \neq 0$, we have a contradiction, because $\rho>0$. Hence, $\alpha=0$, that is $\rho^{\prime} \nearrow 0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. By (3.5), $\rho^{\prime \prime}$ converges to some constant $c$. Since $\rho>0$ and $\rho^{\prime}<0$, we have $c=0$, that is, $\rho^{\prime \prime} \searrow 0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. By (3.5), $\bar{R}$ must be 0 . Assume that $\left(r_{-2}, r_{-1}\right)$ is some maximal interval such that $\rho^{\prime}>0$. By (3.5), we have $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{-2}, r_{-1}\right)$. If $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ at some point, by (3.5), we have $\rho^{\prime} \leq 0$ at this point, which means that $r_{-2}$ must be $-\infty$. However, since $\rho>0$, it cannot happen. Hence, we have $\rho^{\prime} \leq 0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. Therefore, $R \leq 0$ on $M$.

Assume that $r_{2}<+\infty$, that is, $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at $r_{2}$.
Case $1 \bar{R}>0$. In this case,

$$
\rho^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\bar{R}}{4 \rho}>0
$$

at $r_{2}$, hence $\rho^{\prime}>0$ on $\left(r_{2}, r_{3}\right)$, for some $r_{3}$. If $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at $r_{3}$, then $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ at $r_{3}$. Hence, $\rho$ is monotone increasing on $\left(r_{2},+\infty\right)$. If $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at $r_{1}$, then $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ at $r_{1}$, which cannot happen. Therefore, $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $\left(-\infty, r_{2}\right)$. Case $2 \bar{R}=0$. Assume that $\left(r_{-2}, r_{-1}\right)$ is some maximal interval such that $\rho^{\prime}>0$. By (3.5), we have $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{-2}, r_{-1}\right)$. If $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ at some point, by (3.5), then we have $\rho^{\prime} \leq 0$ at this point, which means that

$r_{-2}$ must be $-\infty$. However, since $\rho>0$, it cannot happen. Therefore, we have $\rho^{\prime} \leq 0$ on $\mathbb{R}$.
Case $3 \bar{R}<0$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ at $r_{2}$. Hence, $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{2}, r_{3}\right)$ for some $r_{3}$. If $r_{3}=+\infty$, by the same argument as above, one has $\bar{R}=0$, which is a contradiction. Hence $r_{3}<+\infty$, that is $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at $r_{3}$, which means that there exists $\tilde{r}_{2} \in\left(r_{2}, r_{3}\right)$ such that $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$. By (3.6), $\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}<0$ at $\tilde{r}_{2}$, which cannot happen.

Case (2) of Theorem 2.1. If $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $[0,+\infty)$, since $\rho>0$, the same argument as before shows that a contradiction. Since $\rho>0$ on $(0,+\infty)$, we only have to consider that $\rho^{\prime} \geq 0$ on an interval $\left(0, r_{1}\right)$ for some $r_{1}$. If $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at some point, then we have $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ at this point. Hence one has $\rho^{\prime}>0$ on $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}\right)$ for some $r_{2}$. Iterating the same argument shows that $\rho$ is monotone increasing on $(0,+\infty)$.

# 4. Classification of three-dimensional COMPlete Shrinking GRADIENT YAMABE SOLITONS 

The author showed that any nontrivial complete shrinking gradient Yamabe solitons with $R>\lambda$ is rotationally symmetric and gave some examples with $R=\lambda$ for higher dimensional manifolds (cf. [13]). In this section, we completely classify nontrivial non-flat three-dimensional complete shrinking gradient Yamabe solitons. In particular, we show that nontrivial non-flat three-dimensional complete shrinking gradient Yamabe solitons are rotationally symmetric.

Theorem 4.1. Let $(M, g, F, \lambda)$ be a nontrivial non-flat three-dimensional complete shrinking gradient Yamabe soliton. Then, $(M, g, F, \lambda)$ is either
(1) $\left([0,+\infty), d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(\mathbb{S}^{2}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)$, or
(2) $\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(\mathbb{S}^{2}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)$.

Proof. Case (1) of Theorem 2.1. Since $M$ is compact, it is trivial (cf. [11]).
Case (3) of Theorem 2.1.
By (3.3) and the soliton equation $\rho^{\prime}=R-\lambda$, one has

$$
\rho^{2} \rho^{\prime}+\lambda \rho^{2}+2 \rho^{\prime 2}+4 \rho \rho^{\prime \prime}-\bar{R}=0
$$

By (4.1), $\bar{R}$ is obviously constant. Assume that $R \geq 0$ on $\mathbb{R}$, that is, $\rho^{\prime} \geq-\lambda$. By (4.1), we have

$$
\rho^{\prime \prime} \leq \frac{\bar{R}-2 \rho^{\prime 2}}{4 \rho}
$$

If $\bar{R} \leq 0$, then the positive function $\rho$ is concave. Hence, $\rho$ is constant. By (4.1), we have $\bar{R}=\lambda \rho^{2}>0$, which is a contradiction. Therefore, $\bar{R}$ is positive.

Therefore, we only have to consider the other case, that is, $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$ on some interval $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}\right)$. If $r_{2}=+\infty$, then $\rho=0$ at some point, which cannot happen, because $\rho>0$. Hence, $r_{2}<+\infty$, that is, $\rho^{\prime}=-\lambda$ at $r_{2}$. By (4.1), we have $\rho^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\bar{R}-2 \lambda^{2}}{4 \rho}$ at $r_{2}$.

If $\bar{R} \leq 0$, then $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$. Hence, $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{2}, r_{3}\right)$ for some $r_{3}$. Iterating the same argument shows that $\rho^{\prime} \leq-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{1},+\infty\right)$, which cannot happen. Therefore, $\bar{R}$ is positive.

# 5. Classification of three-dimensional COMPlete EXPANDING GRADIENT Yamabe SOlItONS 

As is well known, in the study of Ricci solitons, much less is understood about the expanding case compared to the shrinking or steady cases. A similar phenomenon appears to occur for Yamabe solitons as well. However, as will be clearly seen in the two-dimensional case discussed later, there are numerous expanding Yamabe solitons, making them a very interesting subject from a geometric standpoint. In this section, we completely classify nontrivial non-flat three-dimensional complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons. Additionally, we provide examples of complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons in any dimension, which do not appear in the steady and shrinking cases.

Theorem 5.1. Let $(M, g, F, \lambda)$ be a nontrivial non-flat three-dimensional complete expanding gradient Yamabe soliton. Then, $(M, g, F, \lambda)$ is either
(1) $\left([0,+\infty), d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(\mathbb{S}^{2}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)$,
(2) $\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(\mathbb{S}^{2}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)$,
(3) $\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid} \mathbb{E}^{2}$ with negative scalar curvature, or
(4) $\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(\mathbb{H}^{2}, \bar{g}_{H}\right)$ with negative scalar curvature, where $\mathbb{E}^{2}$ is the 2-dimensional Euclidean space, and $\left(\mathbb{H}^{2}, \bar{g}_{H}\right)$ is a 2dimensional hyperbolic space.

Proof. Case (1) of Theorem 2.1. Since $M$ is compact, it is trivial (cf. [11]).
Case (3) of Theorem 2.1.

By (3.3) and the soliton equation $\rho^{\prime}=R-\lambda$, one has

$$
\rho^{2} R+2(R-\lambda)^{2}+4 \rho R^{\prime}-\bar{R}=0
$$

By differentiating both sides of (5.1), we have

$$
2 \rho(R-\lambda) R+\rho^{2} R^{\prime}+8(R-\lambda) R^{\prime}+4 \rho R^{\prime \prime}=0
$$

By (5.1), $\bar{R}$ is obviously constant. We consider the case $\bar{R} \leq 0$. Assume that $R>0$ on some open interval $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}\right)$. In this case, by (5.1), one has $R^{\prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}\right)$. If $R=0$ at $r_{1}$, by (5.1), one has $R^{\prime}<0$ at $r_{1}$, which is a contradiction. Hence $R>0$ and $R^{\prime}<0$ on $\left(-\infty, r_{2}\right)$. Therefore, $\rho$ is strictly monotone increasing concave function on $\left(-\infty, r_{2}\right)$. However, since $\rho$ is positive, we have a contradiction. Therefore, we have $R(r) \leq$ 0 on $\mathbb{R}$. Assume that $R=0$ at some point $r_{0}$. By (5.1), one has $R^{\prime}<0$ at $r_{0}$. By (5.2), one has $R^{\prime \prime}>0$ at $r_{0}$, which cannot happen. Therefore, we have $R<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$.

We provide examples of (4) in Theorem 5.1. For $n$-dimensional complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons, an elementary argument yields interesting examples that do not appear in the steady and shrinking cases.

Example. Let $\left(N^{n-1}, \bar{g}\right)$ be an $(n-1)$-dimensional complete Riemannian manifold with constant negative scalar curvature $\bar{R}$. Then, for any $\alpha \in \mathbb{R},(M, g, F, \lambda)=\left(\mathbb{R} \times N^{n-1}, d r^{2}+\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda} \bar{g}, \sqrt{\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda}} r+\alpha, \lambda\right)$ is an $n$-dimensional complete expanding gradient Yamabe soliton with $R=\lambda$.

In particular, $\left(M^{3}, g, F, \lambda\right)=\left(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{H}^{2}, d r^{2}+\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda} \bar{g}_{H}, \sqrt{\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda}} r+\alpha, \lambda\right)$ is a 3 dimensional complete expanding gradient Yamabe soliton with $R=\lambda$, where $\left(\mathbb{H}^{2}, \bar{g}_{H}\right)$ is a hyperbolic surface.

# 6. Classification of two-dimensional COMPLETE GRAdIENT Ricci solitons and Yamabe solitons 

In this section, we provide a proof of nontrivial two-dimensional complete gradient Ricci solitons from the point of view of Yamabe solitons.
Theorem 6.1. Let $\left(M^{2}, g, F, \lambda\right)$ be a nontrivial two-dimensional complete gradient Yamabe soliton. Then $\left(M^{2}, g, F, \lambda\right)$ is one of the following.
Steady case:
Hamilton's cigar soliton.
Shrinking case:
There exists no complete shrinking gradient Yamabe solitons.

# Expanding case: 

(1) $\left(\mathbb{R} \times N^{1}, g=d r^{2}+F^{\prime}(r)^{2} d \theta^{2}, F, \lambda\right)$. The Gaussian curvature $K$ of $\mathbb{R} \times N^{1}$ satisfies $\frac{\lambda}{2}<K \leq 0$, and it is flat near infinity.
(2) $\left(\mathbb{R} \times N^{1}, g=d r^{2}+F^{\prime}(r)^{2} d \theta^{2}, F, \lambda\right)$. The Gaussian curvature $K$ of $\mathbb{R} \times N^{1}$ satisfies $K<\frac{\lambda}{2}$, and it is asymptotically hyperbolic of curvature $\frac{\lambda}{2}$.
(3) $\left([0,+\infty) \times \mathbb{S}^{1}, g=d r^{2}+(\lambda r)^{2} d \theta^{2},-\frac{\lambda}{2} r^{2}+C\right)$ for some $C \in \mathbb{R}$ with flat Gaussian curvature.
(4) $\left([0,+\infty) \times \mathbb{S}^{1}, g=d r^{2}+F^{\prime}(r)^{2} d \theta^{2}, F, \lambda\right)$. The Gaussian curvature $K$ of $[0,+\infty) \times \mathbb{S}^{1}$ satisfies $\frac{\lambda}{2}<K \leq 0$, and it is flat near infinity.
(5) $\left([0,+\infty) \times \mathbb{S}^{1}, g=d r^{2}+F^{\prime}(r)^{2} d \theta^{2}, F, \lambda\right)$. The Gaussian curvature is non-negative, and it is flat near infinity.
(6) $\left([0,+\infty) \times \mathbb{S}^{1}, g=d r^{2}+F^{\prime}(r)^{2} d \theta^{2}, F\right)$. The Gaussian curvature $K$ of $[0,+\infty) \times \mathbb{S}^{1}$ satisfies $K<\frac{\lambda}{2}$, and it is asymptotically hyperbolic of curvature $\frac{\lambda}{2}$.
Here, a manifold $\left(M, g=d r^{2}+\rho(r)^{2} d \theta^{2}\right)$ is called asymptotically flat (resp. hyperbolic of curvature $-c^{2}$ ), if the Gaussian curvature depends only on $r$ and goes to 0 (resp. $-c^{2}$ for some $c \neq 0$ ) as $r \nearrow+\infty$. A manifold $\left(M, g=d r^{2}+\rho(r)^{2} d \theta^{2}\right)$ is called flat (resp. hyperbolic of curvature $-c^{2}$ ) near infinity, if the Gaussian curvature depends only on $r$ and flat (resp. $-c^{2}$ for some $c \neq 0$ ) on some interval $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$.

Proof. It is well known that if $M$ is compact, then it is trivial (cf. [11]). Therefore, we only have to consider (2) and (3) of Theorem 2.1. By the soliton equation, one has

$$
F^{\prime \prime}(r)=R-\lambda
$$

By an elementary fact of the curvature of warped product, one has

$$
R=-2 \frac{F^{\prime \prime \prime}}{F^{\prime}}
$$

Combining these equations, we have

$$
2 \rho^{\prime \prime}+\rho \rho^{\prime}+\lambda \rho=0
$$

where, we denote that $\rho(r):=F^{\prime}(r)$. By differentiating both sides of (6.1), we have

$$
2 \rho^{\prime \prime \prime}+\rho^{\prime 2}+\rho \rho^{\prime \prime}+\lambda \rho^{\prime}=0
$$

By differentiating again one has

$$
2 \rho^{(4)}+3 \rho^{\prime} \rho^{\prime \prime}+\rho \rho^{\prime \prime \prime}+\lambda \rho^{\prime \prime}=0
$$

The equation (6.1) is an autonomous second order equation and can be made into a first order equation by using $\rho$ as a new independent variable. If $\rho^{\prime}=G(\rho)$, then $\rho^{\prime \prime}=\dot{G} G$, and one has

$$
2 \dot{G} G+G \rho+\lambda \rho=0
$$

# Case (3) of Theorem 2.1. 

Case $1 \lambda=0$.
In this case, it is easy to see that the solution of (6.1) is

$$
\rho(r)=2 c_{1}^{2} \tanh \left\{\frac{1}{2}\left(c_{1}^{2} r+c_{1}^{2} c_{2}\right)\right\}
$$

where $c_{1}$ and $c_{2}$ are constants. However, it contradicts $\rho(r)>0$ on $\mathbb{R}$.
Case $2 \lambda>0$.
Assume that $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at some point, that is $G=0$ at some point $\rho_{0}(>0)$, by (6.4), we have

$$
\lambda \rho_{0}=0
$$

which is a contradiction. Therefore, we have $\rho^{\prime}>0$ or $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$.
(I) If $\rho^{\prime}>0$, by (6.1), one has $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$. Therefore, $\rho$ is a positive concave function, which cannot happen.
(II) Assume that $\rho^{\prime}<0$.
(II)-(a) If $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ at some point $r_{0}$, then by (6.1), one has $\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=-\lambda$. Hence, the function $\rho^{\prime}(r)$ has the same value at most 2 times except $-\lambda$.
(II)-(a)-(1) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have $\rho=-\lambda r+c$ for some $c$, which cannot happen, because $\rho>0$.
(II)-(a)-(2) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime}>-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have a contradiction.
(II)-(a)-(3) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have a contradiction.
(II)-(b) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. By (6.1), we have $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$, which cannot happen, because $\rho>0$.

(II)-(c) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. In this case, $\rho$ is a positive concave function, which cannot happen.

Case $3 \lambda<0$.
Assume that $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at some point. By (6.4), we have a contradiction. Therefore, we have $\rho^{\prime}>0$ or $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$.
(I) Assume that $\rho^{\prime}>0$.
(I)-(a) If $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ at some point $r_{0}$, then by (6.1), one has $\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=-\lambda$. Hence, the function $\rho^{\prime}(r)$ has the same value at most 2 times except $-\lambda$.
(I)-(a)-(1) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have $\rho=$ $-\lambda r+c$ for some $c$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. We only have to consider three cases.
(I)-(a)-(1)-(i) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. In this case, we have $\rho=$ $-\lambda r+c$ on $\mathbb{R}$, which cannot happen, because $\rho>0$.
(I)-(a)-(1)-(ii) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(-\infty, \tilde{r}_{0}\right), \rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\left[\tilde{r}_{0}, r_{0}\right]$. In this case, $\lambda<R \leq 0$, and $M$ is flat near infinity.
(I)-(a)-(1)-(iii) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(-\infty, \tilde{r}_{0}\right), \rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\left[\tilde{r}_{0}, r_{0}\right]$. Since $\rho$ is a positive increasing function with $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(-\infty, \tilde{r}_{0}\right)$, we have a contradiction.
(I)-(a)-(2) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime}>-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have a contradiction.
(I)-(a)-(3) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have a contradiction.
(I)-(b) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. By (6.1), we have $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$. Therefore, we have $\lambda<R<0$. If $\rho^{\prime} \nearrow c(<-\lambda)$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$, then by (6.1) and $\rho$ is monotone increasing, one has $\rho^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow \beta$ for some $\beta>0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Since $\rho^{\prime}<c$, we have a contradiction. Hence, we obtain that $\rho^{\prime} \nearrow-\lambda$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Therefore, $M$ is asymptotically flat.
(I)-(c) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. Since $\rho$ is a positive concave function, it cannot happen.

(II) Assume that $\rho^{\prime}<0$. By (6.1), $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$. Since $\rho$ is positive, $\rho^{\prime} \searrow 0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Therefore, $R<\lambda$ and $R$ goes to $\lambda$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$.

# Case (2) of Theorem 2.1. 

Note that $\rho(0)=0$ and $\rho>0$ on $(0,+\infty)$.
Case $1 \lambda=0$.
In this case, it is easy to see that the solution of (6.1) is

$$
\rho(r)=2 c_{1}^{2} \tanh \left\{\frac{1}{2}\left(c_{1}^{2} r+c_{1}^{2} c_{2}\right)\right\}
$$

where $c_{1}$ and $c_{2}$ are constants. Since $\rho(0)=0$, one has

$$
c_{1}=0 \text { or } c_{2}=0
$$

If $c_{1}=0$, then one has $\rho(r) \equiv 0$, which is a contradiction.
If $c_{2}=0$, then one has

$$
F(r)=4 \log \left(\cosh \left(\frac{c_{1}^{2}}{2} r\right)\right)
$$

It is Hamilton's cigar soliton.
Case $2 \lambda>0$.
Assume that $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at some point, that is $G=0$ at some point, then by (6.4), we have $\rho=0$, which is a contradiction. Therefore, we have $\rho^{\prime}>0$ or $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $(0,+\infty)$.
(I) Assume that $\rho^{\prime}>0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. By (6.1), one has $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. Assume that $\rho \nearrow c^{2}$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$ for some constant $c$, then one has $\rho^{\prime} \searrow 0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Hence, by (6.1), $\rho^{\prime \prime}$ goes to $-\frac{\lambda}{2} c^{2}$. Since $\rho^{\prime}>0$, we have a contradiction. Therefore, $\rho \nearrow+\infty$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. By (6.1), $\rho^{\prime \prime} \searrow-\infty$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$, which is a contradiction, because $\rho^{\prime}>0$ on $(0,+\infty)$.
(II) Assume that $\rho^{\prime}<0$.
(II)-(a) If $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ at some point $r_{0}$, then by (6.1), one has $\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=-\lambda$. Hence, the function $\rho^{\prime}(r)$ has the same value at most 2 times except $-\lambda$.

(II)-(a)-(1) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have $\rho=-\lambda r+c$ for some $c$, which cannot happen, because $\rho>0$.
(II)-(a)-(2) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime}>-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have a contradiction.
(II)-(a)-(3) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have a contradiction.
(II)-(b) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. By (6.1), we have $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$, which cannot happen, because $\rho>0$.
(II)-(c) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. In this case, $\rho$ is a positive monotone decreasing concave function, which cannot happen.

Case $3 \lambda<0$.
Assume that $\rho^{\prime}=0$ at some point, that is $G=0$ at some point, then by (6.4), we have $\rho=0$, which is a contradiction. Therefore, we have $\rho^{\prime}>0$ or $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $(0,+\infty)$.
(I) Assume that $\rho^{\prime}>0$ on $(0,+\infty)$.
(I)-(a) If $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ at some point $r_{0}$, then by (6.1), one has $\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=-\lambda$. Hence, the function $\rho^{\prime}(r)$ has the same value at most 2 times except $-\lambda$.
(I)-(a)-(1) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have $\rho=$ $-\lambda r+c$ for some $c$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. We only have to consider three cases.
(I)-(a)-(1)-(i) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. In this case, we have $\rho=-\lambda r+c$ on $(0,+\infty)$. Since $\rho(0)=0$, we have $F(r)=-\frac{\lambda}{2} r^{2}+C$ for some $C$.
(I)-(a)-(1)-(ii) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(0, \tilde{r}_{0}\right), \rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\left[\tilde{r}_{0}, r_{0}\right]$. In this case, $\lambda<R \leq 0$, and $M$ is flat near infinity.
(I)-(a)-(1)-(iii) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(0, \tilde{r}_{0}\right), \rho^{\prime \prime}=0$ on $\left[\tilde{r}_{0}, r_{0}\right]$. In this case, we have $R \geq 0$ and $M$ is flat near infinity.
(I)-(a)-(2) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime}>-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have a contradiction.

(I)-(a)-(3) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. In this case, $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$ on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. By (6.1), we have a contradiction.
(I)-(b) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. Hence, $\rho$ is a monotone increasing convex function, which induces that $\rho \nearrow+\infty$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. By (6.1), we have $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$. Therefore, we have $\lambda<R<0$. If $\rho^{\prime} \nearrow c(<-\lambda)$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$, then by (6.1), one has $\rho^{\prime \prime} \nearrow+\infty$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Since $\rho^{\prime}<c$, we have a contradiction. Therefore, $\rho \nearrow-\lambda$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$, and $M$ is asymptotically flat.
(I)-(c) Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. By (6.1), we have $\rho^{\prime}>-\lambda$, that is, $R>0$. Note that $\rho(0)=0$. By integrating both sides of $\rho^{\prime}>-\lambda$, one has $-\lambda r<\rho(r)$. Therefore, $\rho \nearrow+\infty$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Assume that $\rho^{\prime} \searrow c(>-\lambda)$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. By (6.1), one has that $\rho^{\prime \prime} \searrow-\infty$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Since $\rho^{\prime}>0$, we have a contradiction. Therefore, we have $\rho^{\prime} \searrow-\lambda$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$, and $M$ is asymptotically flat.
(II) Assume that $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. By (6.1), $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $(0,+\infty)$. Since $\rho$ is positive, $\rho^{\prime} \searrow 0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. Therefore, $R<\lambda$ and $R$ goes to $\lambda$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$.

Remark 6.2. For two-dimensional solitons, Theorem 6.1 solves many problems (see for example Page 51 of [7]).

abstract:
In this paper, we completely classify nontrivial non-flat three-dimensional
complete gradient Yamabe solitons. Furthermore, by considering Ricci solitons
from the point of view of Yamabe solitons, we provide a proof of the complete
classification of nontrivial two-dimensional complete gradient Ricci solitons.
